items.title: Hyperlume wants to make chip-to-chip communication faster and more efficient
items.author: Mohsen Asad, Hossein Fariborzi, Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Hyperlume, based in Ottawa, aims to enhance chip-to-chip communication efficiency in data centers.
- The company has developed a microLED technology that outperforms traditional copper connections in speed and energy consumption.
- Co-founder Mohsen Asad emphasized the growing need for low-latency communication in the era of AI and large language models.
- Hyperlume started in 2022 and now collaborates with early customers, working towards broader market access post-product validation.
- The firm recently secured $12.5 million in seed funding to expand its workforce and enhance technology development.

items.title: Superhuman introduces AI-powered categorization to reduce spammy emails in your inbox
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Superhuman launches Auto Label feature for email categorization, automatically tagging emails as marketing, pitch, social, and news.
- Feature allows users to create custom labels and auto-archive certain categories for a cleaner inbox.
- Users can now create Split Inbox views based on custom filters like specific subjects or domains.
- New reminder feature surfaces unanswered emails after a set time, with AI drafting follow-up messages.
- Future plans include integrating with knowledge bases and developing IFTTT-styled workflows to automate email handling.

items.title: Augury raises $75M at $1B+ valuation for AI to detect malfunctions in factory machines
items.summary:
- Augury has raised $75 million in funding for AI-based hardware to detect machine malfunctions.
- The company aims to expand its customer base and enhance technology that monitors vibrations, sound, and temperature.
- Augury analyzes over half a billion hours of machine data, claiming to have the largest dataset of mechanical signals.
- This funding is part of an ongoing Series F round, expected to total around $100 million.
- Major investors include Lightrock, Insight Venture Partners, and Qualcomm Ventures, among others.
- The company's revenue has increased five-fold since its last fundraising round in 2021, with clients including major manufacturers like PepsiCo and Nestle.
- Augury's sensors help machines by digitizing knowledge, addressing the talent shortage in the manufacturing sector.

items.title: NIH funding uncertainty spurs new biotech venture fund
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- The Trump administration directed the NIH to limit specific types of funding for research institutions.
- A federal judge temporarily blocked this policy change, but funding for early-stage biotech startups may still be delayed or eliminated.
- In response to this uncertainty, a new pre-seed venture fund called Altitude Lab Pre-seed Venture Fund has been launched.
- The fund aims to invest $100,000 to $250,000 in 10 to 15 biotech companies, especially those qualified for NIH's SBIR grants.
- The fund will be managed by Altitude Lab, a non-profit life sciences accelerator established by Recursion.
- Recursion's CEO, Chris Gibson, emphasizes the importance of SBIR funding for biotech startups and their chances of raising private money.
- The fund will also provide office and lab space for a year to supported startups in Salt Lake City, aspiring to create a biotech ecosystem.

items.title: Murena now sells a ‘deGoogled’ Pixel Tablet
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- Murena offers a deGoogled version of the Pixel Tablet running the /e/OS open source operating system.
- The tablet features a 10.95-inch LCD display, 128 GB storage, and 8 GB RAM, priced at €539 (or $549 in the U.S.).
- Users can access an app marketplace called App Lounge for downloading apps anonymously, with some limitations for paid apps.
- Murena also provides alternative privacy-focused apps, including freemium storage and office suite options.

items.title: Palo Alto Networks warns of another firewall vulnerability under attack by hackers
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Palo Alto Networks confirmed hackers are exploiting a vulnerability in PAN-OS to breach unpatched customer networks.
- The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-0108, was discovered by Assetnote and is currently under active attack.
- Attackers are combining this vulnerability with previously disclosed flaws CVE-2024-9474 and CVE-2025-0111 to target unsecured web management interfaces.
- GreyNoise has reported 25 IP addresses actively exploiting the vulnerability, indicating an uptick in activity since only 2 addresses were noted earlier in February.
- The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to execute PHP scripts, potentially leading to unauthorized access to systems.
- The highest levels of attack traffic have been observed in the U.S., Germany, and the Netherlands.
- The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.

items.title: Guidde taps AI to help create software training videos
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Guidde is a startup founded by Yoav Einav and Dan Sahar in 2020 to simplify the creation of corporate training videos using AI.
- The platform automatically captures user activity within applications and converts it into engaging video training clips, featuring AI-generated voiceovers and editing tools.
- Guidde recently expanded its offerings with a personalized video recommendation feature called Guidde Broadcast, likened to 'Netflix for organizations.'
- As of now, the platform serves over 100,000 users across 2,000 organizations, including notable companies like American Eagle Outfitters and Nasdaq.
- The startup secured $15 million in funding led by Qualcomm Ventures, increasing its total funding to $30 million to enhance localization tools and market presence.

items.title: A former Etsy product manager built an AI-powered app for new parents
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Amanda DeLuca launched the parenting management app [Riley](https://www.rileyapp.com/) to address parental anxiety based on personal experience.
- The app tracks sleep, diaper changes, vaccines, and feeding, providing AI-powered insights for optimal baby care.
- Riley is currently in public beta with a subscription model: $14.99/month, $11.99/month for a quarter, or $9.99/month for a year.
- Future plans include expanded onboarding for personalized suggestions and additional training resources for parents.
- Riley raised $3.1 million in a seed round led by True Ventures, aiming to provide science-backed parental guidance.

items.title: X doubles its Premium+ plan prices after xAI releases Grok 3
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- X has increased its Premium+ subscription plan price to almost $50 per month following the release of xAI's Grok 3.
- The U.S. price is now $40 monthly and $350 yearly; significant hikes noted in the UK and Europe.
- This marks the second price increase in recent months, previously rising from $16 to $22 per month.
- Some Grok 3 features are reserved for a new SuperGrok plan, limiting features available to Premium+ subscribers.
- Pricing discrepancies observed on X's platform, with differing amounts shown during sign-up and checkout.

items.title: Hyundai’s new Tesla charging port comes up short
items.summary:
- The 2025 Hyundai Ioniq 5 is equipped with Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS) port, intended to increase compatibility with Tesla Supercharging stations.
- Actual testing revealed that the charging cord from a Tesla station did not reach the Ioniq 5's charge port, necessitating drivers to find alternative stations or take up extra space at Tesla chargers.
- Hyundai’s Ioniq 5 can recharge from 10% to 80% in about 20 minutes at a CCS charger, while it can take up to 30 minutes at NACS chargers.
- Hyundai offers a choice between a $400 charging credit or a free home charger with Ioniq 5 purchase.
- The new model has improved battery capacity, with standard and extended range options increasing from 63 kWh to 84 kWh, offering up to 318 miles of range.
- The 2025 Ioniq 5 starts at $43,975 and features tech upgrades like wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, as well as over-the-air updates.

items.title: Kuda and CEO face allegations of sex discrimination and unfair dismissal from former executive, per filing
items.summary:
- Kuda Technologies is facing an employment tribunal case due to allegations of sex discrimination and unfair dismissal by former CPO Rosemary Hewat.
- Hewat claims she was forced out in April 2024 after facing prolonged mistreatment and that the CEO, Babatunde Ogundeyi, fostered a toxic work environment.
- The legal documents allege discrepancies in employee stock options and failed attempts to address workplace grievances, culminating in her dismissal in February 2024, which Hewat believes was retaliatory.

items.title: Pokémon Go maker Niantic is reportedly selling its games division
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Niantic is reportedly exploring a sale of its game development business for about $3.5 million.
- The potential buyer is mobile game developer Scopely, owned by Saudi Arabia's Savvy Games Group.
- Niantic rose to fame with its augmented reality game Pokémon Go, launched in 2016, but has faced challenges since then, including layoffs and project cancellations.
- Niantic laid off 8% of its staff in 2022 and 230 employees in 2023, canceling games related to NBA and Marvel.

items.title: Humane’s AI Pin is dead, as HP buys startup’s assets for $116M
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Humane announces acquisition of its assets by HP for $116 million.
- Discontinuation of AI Pin sales; devices will stop functioning on February 28, 2025.
- AI Pin users advised to transfer data; customer support for AI Pin will dissolve on same date.
- HP includes Humane's engineers and technology, including CosmOS AI operating system, to form an AI innovation lab.
- Humane previously aimed for a higher acquisition price of $750 million to $1 billion in 2024.

items.title: Humane’s AI Pin is dead, as HP buys startup for $116M
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Humane has been acquired by HP for $116 million, leading to the discontinuation of its AI Pin sales.
- Customers have been notified that their AI Pins will stop working on February 28, 2025, at 12 PM PST, ceasing connectivity and functionality.
- Humane will dissolve its customer support team for the AI Pin on the same date and has advised users to back up their data.

items.title: Trump admin reverses hydropower layoffs that sparked grid stability fears
items.summary:
- The Trump administration instituted cuts to federal agencies managing hydropower, laying off 13% to 20% of employees, raising concerns about grid stability.
- Criticism from lawmakers led to the rehiring of some laid-off staff.
- Power Marketing Administrations manage the sale and transmission of hydropower from federal dams, supporting electricity for tens of millions across 34 states.

items.title: Google Play Books purchases on iOS now skirt the App Store’s commission
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Google Play Books can now sell e-books and audiobooks directly through its iOS app.
- A new "Get book" button allows users to access the Google Play website for purchases, avoiding Apple's 30% commission on in-app purchases.
- Users can share books with family across different platforms via Google Play’s Family Library.
- This change followed Apple's External Link Account Entitlement granted post-settlement with Japan's JFTC.

items.title: Duolingo ‘killed’ its mascot with a Cybertruck, and it’s going weirdly well
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Duolingo's mascot, Duo the owl, is humorously declared dead after being 'hit by a Cybertruck'.
- CEO Luis von Ahn read a eulogy for Duo on TikTok, causing a significant spike in user engagement.
- Duolingo saw a 25% increase in monthly active Android users and a 38% jump in downloads the day after the announcement.
- The 'Duo or die' campaign allows users to save the mascot by completing lessons and maintaining streaks.
- Duolingo's marketing tactics are seen as aggressive yet clever, paralleling trends in startup engagement strategies.

items.title: Elon Musk staffer created a DOGE AI assistant for making government “less dumb”
items.author: Charles Rollet, Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- A senior staffer of Elon Musk has created an AI chatbot for the Department of Government Efficiency to help eliminate waste.
- The chatbot operates under a DOGE-named subdomain and is powered by Musk's company xAI.
- It applies five guiding principles to propose efficiency measures for the government.
- The chatbot offers some recommendations, like removing bureaucratic layers and suggests emulating leaders like Margaret Thatcher for efficiency.
- There are some notable issues, including hallucinations common in large language models, where the chatbot provided inaccurate names and odd advice.
- The use of AI within DOGE aims to modernize the U.S. government, with potential revenue implications for xAI due to API usage.

items.title: Apple purges apps without contact info from EU app store, as DSA deadline hits
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Apple has removed EU apps without required contact information to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA).
- The deadline for providing developer contact details was February 17, 2025, and non-compliance led to app removals as of February 18, 2025.
- Smaller and indie developers, who often do not publicize contact info, face significant challenges meeting the new guidelines.

items.title: Safe Superintelligence, Ilya Sutskever’s AI startup, is reportedly close to raising roughly $1B
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Safe Superintelligence, founded by Ilya Sutskever, is nearing a $1 billion fundraising round at a $30 billion valuation.
- VC firm Greenoaks Capital Partners is leading the deal with a pledge of half a billion dollars.
- The startup has previously raised from Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, and DST Global but is not generating revenue yet.

items.title: Amazon, Microsoft, and Exxon want to make scandal-plagued carbon markets more trustworthy
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Amazon, Exxon, and Microsoft have created a task force to improve the integrity of voluntary carbon markets.
- The Bipartisan Policy Center organized the task force, which aims to draft recommendations for transparent and fair carbon markets.
- The task force includes 17 independent members and focuses on restoring credibility in light of scandals in the carbon market.
- Reports exposed that many carbon credits sold by Verra were deemed effectively worthless, leading to significant concern over the legitimacy of carbon markets.
- Microsoft’s carbon emissions rose by nearly 30% in 2023, while Amazon's progress towards emissions reduction has stalled despite investments in renewable energy.
- Microsoft purchased over 7 million metric tons of carbon credits last month, as companies strive to meet net-zero targets.

items.title: Thinking Machines Lab is ex-OpenAI CTO Mira Murati’s new startup
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Former OpenAI CTO Mira Murati has announced her new startup, [Thinking Machines Lab](https://thinkingmachines.ai/), focusing on AI.
- The startup aims to build customizable AI systems that are more widely understood and capable.
- Murati serves as CEO, with OpenAI co-founder John Schulman as chief scientist and ex-chief research officer Barret Zoph as CTO.
- The company aims to address gaps in AI capabilities and improve public understanding and customization of AI technologies.
- Thinking Machines Lab is committed to AI safety and intends to prevent misuse while sharing best practices for building safe AI systems.

items.title: VC giant Insight Partners confirms January cyberattack
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Insight Partners confirmed a cyberattack occurred in January.
- The attack, a sophisticated social engineering incident, was detected on January 16.
- The firm has over $90 billion in assets and has notified its stakeholders about the breach.
- The nature of the incident remains undisclosed, including whether any data was stolen.
- Insight Partners reassured partners to enhance security protocols.

items.title: Fintech fundraising is giving me 2021 flashbacks
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Tabby raises $160 million at a $3.3 billion valuation, doubling its previous worth in 18 months.
- Zeta raises $50 million from a strategic investor, reaching a $2 billion valuation, up from $1.15 billion in 2021.
- Stripe is considering another shareholder sale potentially valuing the company at over $85 billion.
- Raenest raises $11 million for expanding its multi-currency account service in Africa.
- Affinity Africa secures $8 million to enhance digital banking in Ghana.
- Coinbase looks to re-enter the Indian market after a year of operations suspension.

items.title: Fiverr wants gig workers to offload some of their work to AI
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Fiverr introduces a program allowing freelancers to train AI on their work and automate tasks.
- This initiative is aimed at voiceover and graphic design freelancers, allowing them to charge customers for AI-generated work.
- Fiverr CEO Micha Kaufman emphasizes supporting gig workers with credit and compensation while scaling their work.
- The gig market is challenged by generative AI, with many roles facing reduced demand.
- The “Personal AI Creation Model” enables freelancers to configure AI based on their prior projects and set usage fees.
- Freelancers remain owners of the generated work produced by their AI model.
- Fiverr is prioritizing the privacy of freelancers by not using their data to create competing models.
- A “Personal AI Assistant” will be available for monthly fees, helping freelancers manage client interactions effectively.
- Fiverr plans to reward top-performing contractors with shares in the company.

items.title: Facebook now only stores live videos for 30 days, will delete old broadcasts
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Facebook announced that live videos will now only be stored for 30 days; previously, they were stored indefinitely.
- Effective immediately, all live videos older than 30 days will be deleted, with users notified and given 90 days to download or transfer their content.
- Users can store videos in cloud services or convert them into reels; Facebook is promoting these reels as part of the new policy.
- If more time is needed for downloads, users can defer deletion by six months; failure to act will result in permanent deletion.
- Facebook is launching new download tools to assist users in managing their live video content.

items.title: Amazon kills ‘Inspire,’ its TikTok-style feed for discovering products
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Amazon is shutting down its TikTok-like feature ‘Inspire’ designed for discovering products.
- The company stated that the move aligns with customer feedback and that ‘Inspire’ is no longer needed.
- This shutdown occurs amid TikTok's uncertain status in the U.S., which could have made ‘Inspire’ a viable alternative for product discovery.
- Amazon has formed partnerships with Instagram and Snap to enhance shopping experiences on their platforms.
- ‘Inspire’ was launched in 2022 as part of the growing social commerce trend, but faced challenges in creator engagement and compensation issues.
- Amazon indicated that customers can still find product inspiration through other avenues and new AI features.

items.title: OpenAI may give board special voting rights to ward off takeover attempts
items.summary:
- OpenAI is considering granting special voting rights to its non-profit board to prevent hostile takeover attempts.
- This would enable the board to overrule major investors and maintain some authority as the company transitions to a for-profit structure.
- Recently, Elon Musk's group offered $97.4 billion to buy OpenAI’s nonprofit, which was unanimously rejected by the board.
- OpenAI plans to separate its nonprofit and for-profit arms by late 2026.

items.title: Hackers planted a Steam game with malware to steal gamers’ passwords
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Valve removed a Steam game called PirateFI, found to contain malware.
- Security researchers discovered the malware, an info-stealer named Vidar, was distributed via modified games.
- Vidar can steal various types of sensitive data, including passwords and cryptocurrency wallet information.
- Researchers suspect that PirateFI was a tactic to spread Vidar and was not a legitimate game.
- Infostealers like Vidar are often sold as malware-as-a-service, complicating attribution.
- The game was reportedly built using an existing game template, making it easy to deploy malicious software.

items.title: The people in Elon Musk’s DOGE universe
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has created a network of tech talents from his companies like Tesla and SpaceX.
- This ecosystem now intersects with U.S. federal government initiatives, particularly through the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
- The article identifies individuals in Musk's network, detailing their connections and entries into his orbit.
- Notable figures include Elon Musk (DOGE Lead), Steve Davis (long-time Musk insider), and Nicole Hollander (X employee).
- The White House emphasizes that DOGE aligns with government efficiency efforts and complies with federal laws.

items.title: X challenges German court order granting data access to election researchers
items.summary:
- A Berlin court ordered X to provide access to data for research on election risks.
- X is challenging the court's order, citing due process and user privacy concerns.
- The data access debate involves compliance with the EU's Digital Services Act.
- Civil groups involved: Democracy Reporting International and the German Society for Civil Rights.
- The election is scheduled for February 23, raising urgency for the data access research.

items.title: Meta announces LlamaCon, its first generative AI dev conference
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta announced its first developer conference focused on generative AI, named LlamaCon, scheduled for April 29.
- The conference aims to share updates on open-source AI developments and how developers can utilize Meta's AI technologies.
- The company plans significant investment in AI, reportedly up to $80 billion in 2025, while it faces competition from the Chinese AI company DeepSeek.

items.title: Bluesky adds a ‘followers only’ reply option
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Bluesky introduced a 'followers only' reply option to limit replies to your posts.
- The app also includes a 'search posts' feature for user profiles.
- This update aims to help manage conversations and reduce 'content collapse.'
- Users can adjust settings for these features in the app’s Settings section under Moderation > Interaction Settings.
- Update to version 1.98 required for access to new features.

items.title: Fetii’s group rideshare app for young people attracts funding from Mark Cuban, YC
items.author: Matthew Iommi, Justin Rath
items.summary:
- Fetii is a group rideshare service launched by Matthew Iommi and Justin Rath in 2020 to address the lack of convenient transport options for groups.
- Operating in 68 cities across six states, Fetii transports over 200,000 passengers monthly, with 75%-80% of rides on-demand.
- The Austin-based startup raised $7.35 million in a seed round led by Mark Cuban to expand into new markets including Florida, California, and Massachusetts.
- The platform uniquely enables each rider in a group to pay individually using QR codes, simplifying group payments.
- Mark Cuban invested after hearing positive feedback from his daughter about the service, seeing potential for Fetii to go global.

items.title: Hightouch raises $80M on a $1.2B valuation for marketing tools powered by AI
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Hightouch, co-founded by a former Segment engineer, announces $80 million funding led by Sapphire Ventures.
- This funding increases Hightouch's post-money valuation to $1.2 billion, doubling its valuation from 2023.
- The investment will aid in tech development, business growth, and hiring for their AI-powered marketing platform.

items.title: Lingo.dev is an app localization engine for developers
items.author: Max Prilutskiy, Veronica Prilutskaya
items.summary:
- Lingo.dev is a new AI-powered app localization engine designed for developers, providing a simpler way to localize applications.
- Recently raised $4.2 million in seed funding, backed by Initialized Capital and Y Combinator.
- Founded by Max Prilutskiy and Veronica Prilutskaya, previously launched a SaaS startup sold last year.
- Offers an API integration for translating app content with support for front-end localization and business content.
- Utilizes multiple large language models (LLMs) to enhance translation accuracy and context awareness.
- Plans to introduce features that analyze app UI screenshots to improve localization context.

items.title: As US newspaper outages drag on, Lee Enterprises blames cyberattack for encrypting critical systems
items.summary:
- Lee Enterprises reports ongoing cyberattack causing disruptions for over three weeks.
- Forensic analysis ongoing to determine if sensitive data was compromised in the ransomware attack.
- Anticipated further outages affecting operations including distribution, billing, and payments.
- Several newspapers, including Winston-Salem Journal and two Oregon-based papers, have experienced printing delays.
- Lee Enterprises is one of the largest newspaper publishers in the U.S., servicing 72 publications.
- Material impact on the company's financial results is considered likely.

items.title: Legal tech startup Luminance, backed by the late Mike Lynch, raises $75M
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Luminance raised $75 million in a Series C funding round led by Point72 Private Investments.
- It claims to offer highly accurate legal AI solutions and has raised over $165 million to date.
- The startup features over 700 clients across 70 countries, including big names like AMD and Rolls-Royce.
- Luminance uses a Legal Pre-trained Transformer, trained on over 150 million verified legal documents.
- The funding round also included participation from Forestay Capital and existing investors.

items.title: Level Zero Health banks $6.9M to prove wearable medtech can take the strain out of hormone testing
items.summary:
- Level Zero Health raised $6.9 million in pre-seed funding to develop a continuous hormone monitoring device.
- The startup aims to eliminate invasive blood draws and support research for hormone-related treatments.
- The team plans to create a stepping stone single-use product for intermittent hormone testing next year.
- The target market for their technology includes both women’s and men’s health issues.
- Clinical trials for the first device are expected to conclude by next year, with hopes for FDA and CE marking approval.

items.title: X doubles its Premium+ plan prices after xAI releases Grok 3
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- X has raised its Premium+ subscription price to $50 per month after xAI released Grok 3.
- The previous price increase was in December, raising it from $16 to $22 per month.
- Users only have access to some features like 'deep search' and 'reasoning'; other Grok 3 features require a SuperGrok plan.
- Inconsistent pricing on X shows variations between $39.83/month and $50/month for the Premium+ plan.

items.title: Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, releases its latest flagship model, Grok 3
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI launched Grok 3, its latest flagship AI model, with enhanced capabilities for iOS and web apps.
- Grok 3, developed using a significant data center with 200,000 GPUs, reportedly possesses 10x more computing power than its predecessor, Grok 2.
- The model includes variations like Grok 3 mini for quicker responses and Grok 3 Reasoning for thorough problem-solving, aiming to outperform OpenAI’s o3-mini model.
- Grok 3 introduces features like DeepSearch for AI-powered research and is set to have a “voice mode” and an enterprise API in the near future.
- A subscription called SuperGrok, priced at $30/month, will provide enhanced features including reasoning capabilities and unlimited image generation.

items.title: Thousands protest Elon Musk’s DOGE in NYC on Presidents’ Day
items.summary:
- Over 10,000 protesters gathered in NYC on Presidents’ Day against Elon Musk’s DOGE and the Trump administration.
- Protesters expressed concern over the access to sensitive data and dismantling of federal agencies.
- Actions of DOGE have led to nearly 10,000 federal worker firings and cuts to many government contracts.
- Attendees chanted against Musk, marking it as a significant protest in response to perceived government overreach.

items.title: Nextdoor’s Nirav Tolia thinks he can turn things around with AI; he has a lot riding on it
items.summary:
- Nextdoor has shifted focus from large-scale social media to enhancing local community engagement.
- Growth has stalled due to problems such as misinformation and user disengagement.
- Nirav Tolia, the founder, returned as CEO to improve the platform, holding significant shares worth around $1 billion.
- Recent user engagement is up 13%, with 45.9 million active users reported.
- Plans to integrate AI tools aim to enhance user experience and manage discourse quality.
- Challenges remain in addressing local political discussions and content moderation without suppressing free speech.
- The possibility of taking Nextdoor private has been considered in discussions about its future strategy.

items.title: Are your noise-canceling headphones messing with your head?
items.summary:
- Noise-canceling headphones may have side effects beyond hearing damage.
- A BBC report raises concerns about their impact on the brain's sound processing abilities.
- A case study mentions a woman diagnosed with audio processing disorder (APD) after regular use of noise-canceling headphones.
- Five U.K. audiology departments noted an increase in young people with sound processing issues.
- Experts suggest noise-canceling technology might hinder the brain's natural sound filtering abilities, and more research is needed.

items.title: The New York Times has greenlit AI tools for product and edit staff
items.summary:
- The New York Times allows product and editorial teams to utilize AI tools, including a new internal AI summary tool called Echo.
- Staff is encouraged to use AI for editing, brainstorming questions, and research, but must not use it for drafting or significantly revising articles.
- The publication plans to implement AI for voiced articles and language translations, while it is involved in a lawsuit against OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright violations related to AI training.

items.title: The hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Overview of advanced AI models released since 2024, detailing their uses and benefits.
- Highlights models from major companies like OpenAI, Google, and Mistral, including their specific capabilities.
- Discussion on AI model performance and potential issues, such as hallucinations and censorship.

items.title: These are the hottest AI models, what they do, and how to use them
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Overview of the fast-paced development of AI models by companies like Google, OpenAI, and Anthropic.
- Compiled list includes advanced AI models released in 2024 and 2025, detailing their uses and best applications.
- Notable models include OpenAI's o3-mini, designed for STEM tasks, and Google Gemini 2.0 Pro, excelling in coding and long text processing.
- OpenAI's Deep Research offers in-depth research functionality, while Mistral Le Chat serves as a multimodal AI assistant.
- The article emphasizes the quantity of AI models, such as those hosted on HuggingFace, and ongoing updates to the list of new models.

items.title: Trump fires hundreds of air traffic support staff as SpaceX visits FAA command center
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- The Trump Administration has begun firing hundreds of FAA employees maintaining air traffic control infrastructure.
- Firings started late Friday night, coinciding with SpaceX's involvement in creating a new air traffic control system.
- The Professional Aviation Safety Specialists (PASS) union indicates probationary workers were affected, who are not air traffic controllers.
- Employees were informed of their termination via late-night emails from a non-government address.
- The fired workers included aircraft certification specialists, aviation tech system specialists, and others critical to aviation safety.
- Congress has pushed for FAA to address safety issues and modernize its systems, with recent attention on several aviation incidents.
- SpaceX team is visiting the FAA command center to improve the air traffic control system.

items.title: What the US’ first major AI copyright ruling might mean for IP law
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A U.S. federal judge issued a summary judgment in a case against Ross Intelligence by Thomson Reuters regarding AI training material.
- The judge ruled Ross infringed on Reuters' intellectual property by using headnotes from Westlaw for its AI legal research tool.
- The judge deemed Ross' argument of transformative use unconvincing, as it did not add new meaning or purpose.
- The ruling may influence other pending AI copyright cases, although its narrow application is noted.
- The decision distinguishes between Ross' AI, which does not generate content, and generative AI, leading to further discussions on fair use in AI training data.

items.title: X is blocking links to Signal, a secure messaging platform used by federal workers
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s X (formerly Twitter) is blocking links to Signal.me, used for secure messaging.
- This blocking affects direct messages, public posts, and profile pages, first reported by Disruptionist.
- Nearly 10,000 federal workers have been fired in a move to cut federal spending, leading to increased use of Signal's secured messaging for whistleblowing. 
- Attempts to share Signal links resulted in error messages indicating the action could not be completed.
- Musk's actions have drawn scrutiny and accusations of censorship regarding differing opinions.
